question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
\emph{For this short-answer question, only the answers (placed in the
boxes) will be marked.}

On what interval(s) is the graph of \emph{y} =
2\emph{x}\textsuperscript{4} - 4\emph{x}\textsuperscript{3} -
9\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} - x + 3 concave down?
sols:
The graph of a function is concave down where its second derivative is
negative. We are given the function

\[\displaystyle
f(x) = 2x^4 - 4x^3 - 9x^2 - x + 3\] Its derivative is

\[\displaystyle
f'(x) = 8x^3 - 12x^2 - 18x - 1\] and its second derivative is

\[\displaystyle
f''(x) = 24x^2 - 24x - 18 = 6(4x^2-4x-3)\]

We need to know the sign of the second derivative, so we find the roots
of the polynomial 4\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} - 4\emph{x} -3. Its
discriminant is Δ = 16 - 4*4*(-3) = 64 and so its roots are (4 + 8)/8 =
3/2 and (4-8)/8 = -1/2.

Since \emph{y} = 4\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} - 4\emph{x} -3 is a
concave up parabola, we know it will be negative on the interval (-1/2,
3/2) and positive elsewhere and hence the curve \emph{y} =
2\emph{x}\textsuperscript{4} - 4\emph{x}\textsuperscript{3} -
9\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2} - \emph{x} + 3 will be concave down on that
same interval.
hints:
What is the link between the concavity of a graph and its second
derivative?
